loans.name: Magreth

texts.en:
Magreth is 35 years old and is married with 3 children, ages 8-18. Magreth is a hair dresser and owns a small salon , which she started in 2007. Everyday, she works from 8am to 7.30pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $275 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more items for her business.

loans.name: Hasija

texts.en: Hasija H. is from Maglaj and she lives there together with her husband. Her husband works and he is earning around 500 KM (about US$ 400). This is her first loan through MCO WWI  in the amount of US$ 975. Hasija will use this loan to buy new multi-purpose vacuum cleaner  for her household. She can earn additional money by cleaning furniture in other households.

loans.use: To buy new multi-purpose vacuum cleaner

loans.name: Claribel Group

texts.es:
The focal center of the Adela village is located in the city of El Alto, where the association “Claribel” belongs and works with Pro-Mujer for the past two years, showing gratitude and loyalty to the institution.

The sale of natural products and provisions to locals is the activity of this group; they produce quinua, amaranto and pito de cañahua, in seeds and grounded, sold at markets in La Paz and Cochabamba. To increase their production they need to invest into buying more land in order to cultivate and install some machinery to process their products, they have the dream to form a large enterprise, that generates larger income for their families and give better opportunities of work to others.

Translated from Spanish by N.D., Kiva Volunteer.

El centro focal de Villa Adela esta ubicado en la ciudad de El Alto, a éste pertenece la asociación “Claribel” que trabaja junto a la familia de Pro-Mujer hace dos años, demostrando gratitud y lealtad a dicha institución.

La venta de productos naturales y también abarrotes a nivel local es la actividad principal de este grupo, para darnos una idea mas general, producen quinua, amaranto y pito de cañahua, en grano y también molidos, luego los venden en mercados de la Paz y Cochabamba . Para ampliar su producción necesitan invertir en la compra de un terreno de gran superficie con el fin de instalar sus plantaciones y al mismo tiempo instalar la parte de mecánica para procesar sus productos, tienen el sueño de formar una empresa grande, que genere mayores ingresos para sus familias y además pueda dar oportunidad de trabajo a otros.

loans.use: Need more credit to buy land to cultivate and machinery to process their products / neceistan mayores creditos para comprar areas de plantacion y maquinaria para procesar sus productos.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth A. lives in Ijaniki Lagos State Nigeria and owns a beauty salon. She has been in this business since 2001. Ruth is 40-years-old, married and has five children.

She is asking for this loan to buy more salon materials and also to introduce the sales of shoes and clothes in her salon as an additional business. She expresses her gratitude to all.

loans.use: To buy beauty salon products, shoes and clothing

loans.name: Evaline's Group

texts.en:
Evaline has sold bananas in Arusha since 2002. She is 48 years old, married, and has three children ages 33, 24, and 18. She works daily from 8:00am to 4:00pm, which allows her to earn a profit of approximately $50 each month.

Evaline hopes to use this loan to grow her business. She will share it with her two group members. One group member, Nai, sells maize and the other, Eliakesia, sells milk.

loans.use: To buy more inventory.

loans.name: Nizami

texts.en: Nizami is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Fuzuli town. He has settled in the Fizuli region, in a Bahmanli village. He was born in 1987 and is single. You can see his sister in the picture. Nizami has run a cattle breeding business for 7 years. Now he needs a loan of $1200 to buy two calves to improve his business.

loans.use: To buy 2 calves

loans.name: Ybysuñu Group

texts.es:
El Grupo denominado Ybysunú se conformó en fecha 22 de enero del 2008, dicho grupo fue organizado gracias a que la actual tesorera contacto con la Asesora del programa, se convocó a una reunión donde asistieron todas vecinas y conocidas, las integrantes de este grupo destinan su crédito a diferentes actividades tales como:

Dionicia Verónica Ibáñez – Venta de mercería.

Leoncia Ibáñez – Venta de frutas y verduras.

Eusebia Martínez – Venta de Gallinas.

Saturnina D. – Venta de Gallinas.

Elva N. – Venta de Gallinas.

Blanca A. – Venta de Frutas.

Olga Pérez – Venta de Ropas.

Sara Verón – Venta de Comidas.

Elisa P. – Venta de Gallinas.

Andrea Ibáñez – Venta de mercería.

Martha E. – Venta de mercería.

Simeona A. – Despensa.

Josefina B. – Venta de Gallinas.

Lorenza O. - Despensa.

Lucila López – Venta de Cosméticos.

Olga J. – Despensa.

Pabla R. – Despensa.

El grupo demuestra compañerismo y solidaridad. Todas las integrantes del grupo asisten a las reuniones semanales y realizan actividades para recaudar fondos extras en caso de que surja una eventualidad y demuestra un gran interés al programa y la importancia de cumplir en forma excelente con sus pagos.

El grupo se destaca por el entusiasmo y la honestidad que demuestran una a otra.
texts.en:
The Group called Ybysunú was formed January 22, 2008. This group was organized thanks to the current treasurer contacting the Treasurer of the program, who convened a meeting attended by all neighbors and acquaintances. The members of this group will use their loans for different activities, such as:

Dionicia Verónica Ibáñez - Hardware Sales.

Leoncia Ibáñez - Fruit and Vegetable Sales.

Eusebia Martínez - Chicken Sales.

Saturnina D. - Chicken Sales.

Elva N. - Chicken Sales.

Blanca A. - Fruit Sales.

Olga Pérez - Clothing Sales.

Sara Verón - Food Sales.

Elisa P. - Chicken Sales.

Andrea Ibáñez - Hardware Sales.

Martha E. - Hardware Sales.

Simeona A. - Grocery Store.

Josefina B. - Chicken Sales.

Lorenza O. - Grocery Store.

Lucila López - Cosmetics Sales.

Olga J. - Grocery Store.

Pabla R. - Grocery Store.

This group demonstrates companionship and solidarity. All of the members attend the weekly meetings and carry out activities to raise extra money in case a contingency emerges. They show a great interest in the program and the importance of excellent compliance with repayment.

The group stands out for its enthusiasm and the honesty they show to each other.

Translated from Spanish by Megan Tatman Montgomery, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables, ingredients for food preparation, chickens, cosmetics, clothing, sugar, flour, herbs, meat, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy a cow for breeding.

loans.name: Maria Del Pilar

texts.es:
La señora Maria del Pilar Sánchez de 58 años, su estado civil es casada, tiene 5 hijos los cuales 3 dependen de ella, una hija mujer de 37 años no trabaja, Juan Manuel de 39 años es discapacitado su hijo menor de 4 años cursa el segundo nivel su esposo no labora actualmente, En sus propósitos esta mantener su negocio, que sus hijas y familia tengan una casa propia, además uno de los negocio que mas le gustan es la venta de fríjol por lo que le gustaría seguir adelante con este negocio ya que la situación del país no esta muy estable en sus propósitos tiene el de salir adelante con su familia por lo que todos sus hijos la apoyan es lo que es su negocio.


Ella inicia este negocio que es una pulpería, lo cual tiene 30 años de obtener este establecimiento en la que la expende los productos como: granos básicos  en lo que de alguna manera ella busca el pan de cada día y con su esposo e hijos decide la implantación de este negocio para tratar de salir adelante y es así como decide quedarse con la venta por que además de este negocio posee otros dos como lo es: la venta de nacatamales y un molino para moler maíz, por lo que recurre a este financiamiento para lograr sacar adelante su pulpería ya que tiene que realizar las compras en las diferentes distribuidoras y necesita buscar el lugar mas rentable donde ella pueda obtener los productos que expenderá.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maria Del Pilar S. is fifty-eight years old, married, and has five children. Three of her children are still dependent on her. Her thirty-seven-year-old daughter does not work. Thirty-nine-year-old Juan Manuel is handicapped. Her youngest is four and in his second year of school. Her husband does not work now. Some of the things she intends to do are keep up her business, get her daughters and family their own house, and, because she likes selling beans, succeed with that business so that she can do well in her country's unstable economy. She would still like to go on with this business, as the country's situation is not very stable. She hopes that she and her family can get ahead because all of her children support her in her business. Mrs. Maria Del Pilar's business is a local store. Thirty years ago she obtained this establishment in which she sells products like basic grains, and somehow puts bread on the table. With her husband and children she decided to establish this business to help them to leave in the future. This is why she decides to stay with the business. Plus, two similar business sale items are nacatameles and a mill to grind corn. She turns to this loan to succeed in getting her local store off the ground – she still has to make purchases from different distributors, and she needs to look for the most profitable place to get the products she will sell.

Translated from Spanish by HannahLily P, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence F., a.k.a FF, is 40 years old. She is married and has three children who are currently in school. She has manufactured palm oil for five years now. Palm oil is produced from palm nuts while palm kernel oil is produced from palm kernel. She produces the oil and supplies it to food vendors so they can prepare their meals. She normally switches her production between the two products. That is, after producing palm oil she automatically obtains the raw material to produce palm kernel oil.

She wants to use the loan to buy more bags of palm nuts and an electric milling machine so she can produce the oil in larger quantities. She believes this increased production will augment her income so she can better provide for her family and finance her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called House of Faith Trust Group. Her picture was taken at a group meeting. In this group, members provide social collateral for one another to guarantee the repayment of loans.

loans.use: To buy palm nuts and an electric milling machine

loans.name: Sophal

texts.en:
Mrs. Sophal S. is a villager in Preak Ta Erk village in the Kandal province. She is a housewife who cooks delicious food for her family. Her husband, Mr. Chab Sopheap, is a fisherman. Even though he works hard, they do not earn enough income to support the family. The couple also does not own their own piece of land where they can build a house. Mrs. Sophal S. decided to ask for a loan to add to her savings so they can purchase land build a house for her family.

Mrs. Sophal S. is 41-years-old and the mother of four children. One child is a fisherman, another is a tailor, and the remaining two children attend the local school. Her husband is present with her in the picture.

loans.use: To add money to a savings account and buy a piece of land to build a house for the family.

loans.name: Pasos Firme Group

texts.en:
Avelia operates two significantly differently entrepreneurial activities. Avelia sells both sweets and gasoline. Aided by Esperanza International, Avelia has been able to purchase additional materials, including the needed ingredient to produce her sweets and additional levels of gasoline, to increase the level of sales for both entrepreneurial activities and gain a greater return. Thus far, throughout the life of her business, Avelia has encountered some setbacks including the deaths of loved ones, but her ambition remains to own her own “colmado”, or small store one day, and encourage the growth and education of her children (ages: 18, 15, 11, 9).

Avelia is not alone in her quest to succeed through entrepreneurial activities. Avelia is a member of the micro-finance bank “Pasos Firme”. All the members of the bank are illiterate. Along with the four other women, Avelia is seeking additional loan funds from Esperanza to encourage growth in her business. Other members of Avelia’s microfinance bank run similar entrepreneurial ventures including selling peanut butter and assorted food sales.

On behalf of Esperanza and this group of business entrepreneurs, we would like to thank you for your support!

loans.use: Purchase additional needed materials for sweets and additional gasoline for re-sale

loans.name: Sauda

texts.en:
Mrs. Sauda K., 32, has operated a coffee business in Kabwohe for over 15 years. She is requesting a loan to purchase more bags of coffee. 

Sauda is a married woman with four children, all of whom she hopes to educate with the income from the business and her rental units. Her husband also helps in the running of the business. Her dream is to export coffee.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of coffee.

loans.name: Mougnou (Patience) Group

texts.fr:
Les sept femmes du groupe Mougnou (toutes mariées) avec une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans et 3 enfants,  vivent la plupart dans des  familles polygames à Kamalen Sirakoro un des villages de la commune de Sikasso 3ème région administrative de la république du Mali. .
Elles mènent diverses  activités  qui sont entre autres la vente de poissons fumés,  frais, d’atieké, d’arachide et de chaussures.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle et sont à leur deuxième  prêt de groupe après avoir correctement remboursé le premier.
Avec ce  prêt, elles comptent acheter,  3 colis d’articles de boutique, 50 kg de poissons fumés, 25 kg de poissons frais,  100 kg d’atieké, 250 kg d’arachide, et 12 douzaines de paires de chaussures en plastiques.
Elles s’approvisionnent au marché de Médine et au grand marché de Sikasso.
Les marchandises sont vendues la plupart au comptant ,au marché de Kamalen Sirakoro et dans les villages avoisinants à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Elles envisagent réaliser chacune un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 13.500FCFA  dont une partie sera épargnée et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
The seven women in the Mougnou group (all married) have an average age of 34 and three children, and most live in polygamous families in Kamalen Sirakoro, one of the villages in the district of Sikasso, the Republic of Mali’s third administrative region. They run various businesses, including selling smoked and fresh fish, atieké cassava, peanuts and shoes. In order to meet customer needs, they are working with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso and are on their second group loan, having successfully repaid the first one. They plan to use this loan to buy three boxes of boutique items, 50 kg of smoked fish, 25 kg of fresh fish, 100 kg of atieké, 250 kg of peanuts, and 12 dozen pairs of plastic shoes. They obtain their supplies from the market in Médine and the main market in Sikasso. Most of the goods are sold for cash at Karmalen Sirakoro’s market and in neighboring villages to a clientele composed of both men and women. Each member expects to make a monthly profit of CFA 13,500, half of which will be saved and the other half invested in the business.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy misc. items

loans.name: Abed Al Fattah

texts.en:
Abed A. Fattah is a 59-year-old man who lives in Saida, southern Lebanon with his wife and their child. Abed A. Fattah has been selling clothes and working as a taxi driver since 1992. He requested a loan of 1500 US dollars from A. Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for his shop and do some maintenance work on his taxi. This is his second cycle and he has always paid on time.
His previous loan helped him improve his clothing shop by diversifying his merchandise. Abed A. Fattah is speciA. in his work because he knows how to treat his clients. Abed A. Fattah is an active man who wants to improve his family’s income. His clients can be anybody from his region. When he first started his business, he didn’t have the startup capitA.. In the future, he plans on improving his businesses.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for his shop and do some maintenance work on his taxi.

loans.name: Ky

texts.en: Mrs. Ky S. is a villager in Speu village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land where she cultivates rice. Her husband, Mr. Phan Cheav, is a cow middleman. Since his business is doing well, he wants to expand it. Thus, Mrs. Ky S. decided to ask for a loan to buy more cows for her husband’s business. She hopes to increase their income and improve her family's life. She is 40 years old and the mother of four children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, another is a laborer, and the others are attending the local school. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy more cows for her husband’s business.

loans.name: Rustam

texts.en:
Rustam R. is a 24-year-old trader who rents a store where he sells spare-parts for cars. He has run this business for the last five years. He chose this business because it is a very profitable business and people always come to Rustam in order to purchase quality spare-parts and accessories for their cars.

Rustam is not married and lives with his parents. He dreams of saving some money from his income to build his own store. To approach his dream, he applied for $1200 to purchase more car accessories and spare-parts.

loans.use: To purchase more car accessories and spare-parts

loans.name: Ceta

texts.en:
"I started my business in 2004. My husband and I decided to have a store business. We also have  piggery  at the back of our house. The pigs produced offsprings and we sell the piglets to the pig growers in our location. Before, I was just selling firewood to our neighbors", says Ceta C., the 47-year-old mother of four children.

She would like to ask for a loan of Php 7,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to purchase stocks of feed for her hog business and additional merchandise for her store. The loan will help her improve her number of pigs and her store income as well.

CEVI helps small businesses to grow. It provides not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase additional merchandise for her store and feeds for her backyard hog-raising business

loans.name: Olmahon

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 


Олмахон  Рузиматова  после смерти мужа осталась с четырьмя детьми. Ей надо растить детей. И вот она решила продолжить деятельность своего мужа, который занимался животноводством. Хоть и трудно ей приходилось, но своими усилиями и с помощью своих детей она справляется с этой работой неплохо. Получив прибыль от животноводства она открыла маленькую торговую лавку рядом со своим домом, где торгует  хозяйственными товарами ( мыло, стиральный порошок и т.д.)
 Олмахон услышав о нашей организации и ознакомившись с условиями кредитования, подала заявку на получения кредита в размере 1600 сомони, для откорма скота.
texts.en:
After her husband’s passing, Olmahon R. was left with four children. She needs to raise her children. And so she decided to continue her husband’s business, which is animal husbandry. Although it has been tough, Olmahon, with the help of her children, was able to handle this work well. Once she made a profit from animal husbandry, she opened a small retail stand near her house, where she sells household products (soap, laundry detergent, etc.). Once Olmahon found out about our organization and learned about our financing terms, she requested a loan in the sum of 1600 somoni for livestock feeding.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Livestock feeding

loans.name: Lai

texts.en:
Mrs. Lai K., 37, and her husband, Mr. Chun Nhem, 41, were married in 1985 and have five children: three daughters and two sons. Two of their daughters are garment factory workers, one son is a construction worker and the other children attend school. The family lives along National Road Number Five about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Mr. Chun Nhem used to be a fisherman, but he stopped the business for a while and started a new business as a construction contractor, while Mrs. Lai K. stopped her fish selling business and she hopes to run new business as well. Lai is requesting a loan of $500 in order to buy wooden materials to repair the wall of the house.

loans.use: To buy wooden materials to repair the wall of her house.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B. is from the village of Lantay, Pangatucan, Valencia Bukidnon. She is 38 years old. Josephine is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Josephine owns and operates a business venture in the services sector. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing motorcycle services locally termed as "habal habal" to local community members. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 6000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support the education of her children.

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Bulubandi 1 West Mugozi Margaret Group

texts.en: M. Margaret has been in the poultry business since 2001 – eight years in her business. She is a 30-year-old married business lady blessed with three children, all going to school. She is using this loan to purchase chicks, drugs and feed. She is working very hard to improve upon her business by stocking more chicken feed and so forth. Her hope for the future is to educate her children, enlarge her business, construct a house and, even more, she would love to drive. She wants to at least have a change in her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase chicks, drugs and feed for a poultry business

loans.name: Jeanelyn

texts.en:
Jeanelyn L. started tilling a 1.5 hectare farm since she got married in 2002. Her husband is a farmer. They have two chidren and their eldest child is 6 years old. She started to worry about their growing finances epecially because her eldest started to go to school.

She is asking a loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to pay the farm laborers and to buy rice seeds.She also aspires to get started to a new business which is pigs.

Receiving a loan is really helpful for him to improve her income to support her children and husband.

loans.use: farm laborers, rice seeds

loans.name: Mien's Group

texts.en:
Miến Thị Nguyễn (id: 010117090023) was born in 1968. She lives in Dai Bi – Uy No – D. Anh with her husband, two children, and her morther-in-law. Her husband is a building worker. Her children are small.

Mrs. Miến raises chickens and sells vegetables in the market and has a monthly income of about 4,000,000 VND. She wants to borrow 5,886,000 VND (approx. 335 USD) to breed pigs and poultry.

Mrs. Miến is the group leader of a seven-member group loan offered by SEDA. WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

About the other borrowers in her group:

Huyền Thị Lê (id: 010117090026) was born in 1971 and has four children. She sells fish to restaurants. She wants to borrow 6,758,000 VND (approx. 380 USD) to go to the market.

Đông Thị Phạm (id: 010117090020) was born in 1969 and has two children. She needs 5,886,000 VND (approx. 335 USD) to buy feed for her pigs.

Xuyến Thị Nguyễn (id: 010117090024) was born in 1972 and has two children. She wants to borrow 6,758,000 VND (approx. 380 USD) to buy breeding pigs to sell in the market.

Là Thị Nguyễn (id: 010117090022) was born in 1975 and has two children. She sells gas and spa water. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND (approx. 355 USD) to invest in her business.

Mừng Thị Nguyễn (id: 010117090021) was born in 1976 and has three children. She wants to borrow 6,322,000 VND (approx. 355 USD) to invest in her business.

Hương Thị Đồng (id: 010117090027) was born in 1971. She needs 6,758,000 VND (approx. 380 USD) to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.use: To breed pigs and poultry

loans.name: Lege

texts.en: Lege R. is currently in the business of selling bread and is requesting a loan to purchase more baking materials .  Lege is 31 years old and is Married with a husband that is a peasant. She has 2 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open up a bigger backery BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase baking materials

loans.name: Jolita

texts.en: Jolita C. is from the village of Lugait, Misamis Oriental. She is 49 years old. Jolita is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Jolita owns & operates a business making & selling food. The main source of income for the business comes from selling snacks & other delicacies in the local community. Jolita is just starting this business. In 2009, Jolita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jolita is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the 1st loan taken out by Jolita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Afiwoa

texts.fr: Cette femme habite le quartier d’Agoè à Lomé où elle a ouvert en 2004 une boutique de vente de boissons alcoolisées et des produits de beauté. Cette activité lui permet d’assurer financièrement l’éducation scolaire de ses 03 enfants. Sa boutique est bien connue de nombreux clients qui apprécient le bon accueil qu’elle développe à leur endroit. C’est pour renouveler son stock qu’elle sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 20 cartons de boissons Castel, des mèches, des crèmes de beauté et divers produits cosmétiques. Cette dame n’est pas mariée.
texts.en:
This woman lives in the Agoè district of Lomé, where she opened a store in 2004 selling alcoholic beverages and beauty products. This business allows her to provide financially for the education of her three children. Her store is well-known by many customers who appreciate the hearty welcome and atmosphere she has developed. It is to replenish her stock that she is seeking a loan through WAGES (one of Kiva's field partners) to buy 20 cartons of Castel drinks, hair extensions, beauty creams, and various other cosmetics. This lady is unmarried.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy alcoholic beverages, hair extensions, and body creams

loans.name: Loem

texts.en: Mrs. Loem H. lives in Srae Vong village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns 1-hectare field to cultivate rice. Aside from this, she is a pig breeder. Since this business is going well, she wants to expand it. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy three more piglets and pig food for breeding. She will also use the loan to buy cows for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan. Her husband, Mr.Ngov Seourn, is a construction worker. Mrs. Loem H. is a mother of four children; two are enrolled in the local school but the others are too young to work or study. Her husband is presented on the right of the photo.

loans.use: For piglets, pig feed, and cows

loans.name: Ram Devi

texts.en:
Ram Devi Tamarkar is 43 years old and lives in the Tangal region of Nepal. She is married and lives with her husband and their two sons. She works alongside her husband in their small hotel, which they opened together ten years ago.

Because the number of customers frequenting her hotel has increased in recent years, Ram is seeking a loan of 30,000 NPR to purchase materials for improving the quality of the hotel.

She hopes to use the profits generated by this loan to increase the value of their house and also to provide a better education for their children.

loans.use: to buy materials to improve the quality of their hotel

loans.name: Sergei

texts.en:
Sergei sells men's clothing at the central market in Melitopol town. He's been in this business for six years. His kiosk has a good location, and he offers affordable prices and a large assortment. All these factors help Sergei run his business successfully. Sergei would like to borrow 7,500 hryvnia to purchase more inventory.

Sergei is married. He hopes to make additional income to continue fixing the house where he and his wife live.

loans.use: To  purchase more inventory

loans.name: Alawia

texts.en:
Alawia A. is currently in the business of selling airtime and mobile phones in a shop. She is requesting a loan to stock more mobile phones and airtime. Alawia is 29 years-old and married with a husband that is a soldier. She has three children who go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a hardware shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 female members.

loans.use: To purchase mobile phones and airtime.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to invest in expanding her business

loans.name: Jeyhun

texts.en:
Jeyhun T. is a 33-year-old tailor who has been running his business for the past 10 years. As soon as he finished the special tailoring school, he started as a tailor's assistant and, after a year, he opened his own tailoring studio.  He prepares different kinds of clothes for men, but his best and favourite project is making men's suits. 

He is married and has a daughter. He wishes to provide the best for his family and especially for his beloved daughter. For this purpose, he has applied for a loan of 1600 AZN to purchase a modern sewing machine.

loans.use: To purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Glenda's Group

texts.en:
Glenda K. is from the village of Little Tadian. She is 37 years old. Glenda is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Glenda is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Glenda owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector, raising livestock. The main source of income for the business comes from raising pigs for fattening and sale. Glenda has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP whenever she sells her raised animals.

In 2010, Glenda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Glenda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase livestock feed & other supplies. This will be the first loan taken out by Glenda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase livestock feed & other supplies

loans.name: La Hermandad Group

texts.es:
el grupo La Hermandad esta integrado por tres mujeres que son muy amigas y son dedicadas al comercio,
este grupo esta solicitando el credito para invertirlo en sus negocios. a continuacion se detalla las diferentes actividades que ellas realizan:
 
la señora Gloria Jamileth S. tiene 33 años de edad, vive en union libre con Luis Armando Medina Castro quien se dedica a la construccion, tienen 3 hijos que estan estudiando. doña Gloria se dedica a venta de pescado y camaron, solicita el credito para invertirlo en dicha actividad. en esta epoca de semana santa se vende mucho el pescado.
 
la señora Gloria Argentina M. tiene 52 años de edad, esta casada con el señor Miguel Angel S. quien se dedica  a la construccion, no tienen hijos. La señora M. se dedica a la venta de productos de la canasta basica como ser azucar, harina de maiz, manteca, refrescos, aceite y otros.
esta solicitando el credito para invertirlo en su pulperia
 
La señora Eiby Melissa H. tiene 27 años de edad, vive en union libre con el señor Francisco Zamora quien se dedica a la venta de mariscos.
Tienen 2 hijos pequeños, Eiby se dedica a la venta de productos de consumo popular, tiene una pulperia en su casa de habitacion. ahi vende azucar,café, jugos, jabon, refrescos, pollo, verduras, y tambien pescado. esta solicitando el credito para surtir un poco mas su negocio.
texts.en:
The La Hermandad group is comprised of three women who are very good friends, and they are devoted to commerce. The group is asking for a loan to invest in their businesses. What follows are details of their different economic activities: Gloria Jamileth Sanches is 33 years old and in a common law marriage with Luis Armando Medina Castro, a construction worker. They have three children who go to school. Gloria sells fish and shrimp. She is requesting the loan to invest in this activity. A lot of fish is sold during this time of Holy Week. Gloria Argentina M. is 52, and she is married to Miguel Angel S., a construction worker. They do not have children. Mrs. M. sells basic needs food products like sugar, corn flour, shortening, soft drinks, oil, and others. She is requesting the loan to invest in her mini-market. Eiby Melissa H. is 27, and she is in a common law marriage to Francisco Zamora. He sells seafood. They have two small children. Eiby sells popular consumption products. She has a mini-market in her home. She sells sugar, coffee, juice, soap, soft drinks, chicken, vegetables, and fish. She is requesting the loan to stock her business a little more.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy fish, shrimp, beans, rice, corn, tortillas, sugar, coffee, bread, crackers, churros, soft drinks, soap, pastas, salsas, soup, preserves, juice, shortening, and oil

loans.name: Voang

texts.en:
Voang C., aged 43, is widowed and resides with her husband in Kampong Chnang province, Cambodia. She has four children. 
Voang C. works in the agricultural sector growing rice, and earns approximately $4 USD in revenue per day. She has been engaged in this business since 2004. Two of her children are employed in a local garment factory, earning an income of $3 USD each per day. 
The family's standard of living has improved since C. started her business, so she is requesting a loan of $1,200 USD to expand it by purchasing a machine to grind rice. By doing so, she will be able to use the machine to grind her rice product from the field, and make more money by renting out the machine. This is Voang C.'s third loan from Kiva partner, CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy a machine to grind rice

loans.name: La Buena Union 2,3 Group

texts.en:
Martha is the coordinator of her group la Buena Union (The Good Union), and her story is representative of her group's members and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural area surrounding Hato Mayor — an area where the economy is dominated by agriculture and where running water (none of which is potable), and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home in a simple structure as a single mother with her children.

Martha is excited to be taking out her second loan from Esperanza, having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to buy shampoos and rinses which she sells to the various beauty salons in her neighborhood. She will use the profits to invest in her children's education and save toward sending them to college. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Shampoo and rinse to sell

loans.name: Warlito

texts.en: Warlito, 53, is a rice farmer in Banga, South Cotabato. He also raises ducks for additional income. He needs to purchase feed and fertilizers for his businesses. With limited capital, he requested a loan from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. of 6,000 Php. He supports his family through these businesses. He has 5 children in the family to support.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok M. and her husband, Mr. Nimol Mach, have been married since 2006 and have one young son. The family lives along National Road Number Six, about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh. 

Sok sells fish that her husband catches. The couple also grows vegetables on their farmland in the village and sells them at the Prek Anhchanh market. Sok is asking for her second loan of $600 to purchase a water pumping machine for her vegetable farm.

loans.use: To purchase a water pumping machine for her vegetable farm

loans.name: Daban Road Namubiru Aisha Group

texts.en:
N. Aisha is a business lady, twenty-six years old. She is married with four children, all schooling, and she is looking after two dependents who are schooling, too.

Aisha runs a business selling clothes and she has been running this business so far for five years. She is using the loan to purchase new clothes for sale. She mostly gets her clothes from both Kampala and Kenya. She is an encouraging businesswoman whose dream is to purchase a car.

loans.use: To purchase a new stock of clothes to sell

loans.name: Ou

texts.en:
Ou S., 46, is married and resides with her husband and three children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia, an area known for its palm products.

S. sells porridge and cooked rice in her village for a gross income of USD 16 per day. Her husband is a motor-taxi driver, earning an income of about USD 7 per day.

S. is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 to purchase a motorbike for one her children to become a motor-taxi driver. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike to start a transportation business for one of her children

loans.name: Kanchi

texts.en: Mrs. Kanchi D. lives in Sainbu-Bhaishapati village. She lives with her husband, Mr. Ram hari D., and one son. Her husband is in house construction work and her son works in an electronics shop. Mrs. Kanchi is a farmer, growing different types of vegetables. Due to the lack of technology, most farmers in her area depend on seasonal farming. Mrs. Kanchi sells her vegetables at the local market in the morning and the evening. She is requesting a loan of Rs 30000.00 to buy seeds and fertilizer.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers

loans.name: Melinda

texts.en:
Melinda G. is from the village of San Roque, Enrile, Cagayan. She is 47 years old. Melinda is married and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Melinda owns and operates a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling school products such as pencils, pens, and notebooks in the local community. Melinda has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Melinda joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Melinda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. Melinda is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Melinda from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell.

loans.name: Perla

texts.en:
Perla S. is from the village of Bagong Silang, Iligan City. She is 34 years old and single with one school-aged child. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, buying and selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $175 a month from these activities.

In 2010, Perla joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Perla's 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

location.town: Bagong Silang, Iligan City, Lanao del Norte

loans.name: Christian

texts.en:
Christian L. is a vendor of pumpkins, pumpkin leaves, okra, and dodo at market. She wishes to expand her offerings and and is therefore requesting a loan to stock other fruits, such as gavva and oranges. 

Christian is 21 years old and is married. Her husband is a driver. They have two children, the elder of whom attends school. 

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes eventually to be able to open up and operate a bar.

loans.use: To stock additional fruits such as gavva and oranges for sale

loans.name: Norah

texts.en:
Norah G. is 16 years old and lives in the town of Zana in the Kampala West region of Uganda. She is married and has 1 child. Norah has a business of selling snacks, which she has had for 2 years. Norah has a second business farming in her village.

To help expand her business, Norah has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase oil and flour and pay the farmers. With the help of the loan from BRAC, Norah hopes to generate greater profits and buy food. In the future, Norah hopes to own a hotel. Norah is a member of BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program, which has helped her prospects for the future by increasing her business and helping her to pay the farmers on time. 

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more oil and flour

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua A. is married to a farmer and has five dependents. She sells charcoal and firewood at Elmina. Ekua has attained junior high level of education. Ekua uses her income to help her husband in providing the basic needs of the family. She will use the loan to purchase additional bags of charcoal for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ekua plans to save to build a storehouse for her charcoal.

loans.use: purchase additional bags of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Lidia

texts.es: Lidia Tiene 44 años, ella tiene ya 4 años en el negocio de venta de pollo, tiene un puesto en el mercado el cual le permite tener buenos ingresos los mismos que ahorra para  poder ampliar su puesto y vender tambien verduras y legumbres, por ello solicita el crédito a fin de lograr su sueño, ella cuenta con el apoyo de sus hijos los cuales estan en edad universitaria, ella sueña con poder mejora la calidad de vida de su familia, por lo cual se esfuerza y trabaja mucha par conseguir sus anhelos, se le brinda el crédito por contar con capacidad de pago y buenas referencias personales.
texts.en:
Lidia, age 44, has had a business selling chicken for four years.  She has a stand in the market, which allows her to have good earnings.  She saves her earnings in order to be able to expand her stand to also sell vegetables.

That is why she is requesting a loan to achieve her dream.  Her children, who are college age, help her.  She dreams of being able to improve her family’s quality of life.  That is why she tries hard and works a lot in order to reach her goals.  Good personal references and repayment capacity qualify her for the loan.

loans.use: To buy merchandise

loans.name: Elena's Group

texts.en:
Elena B. Elena, age 49, is the group leader of a nine-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Elena makes and sells handicrafts to tourists and local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over 26 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month. She and her husband have three school-aged children and live in the village of Bacolod, Alcala, Cagayan. 
  
Earlier this year, Elena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. She planned to help improve her living situation and increase her ability to engage in business activities. Elena is requesting her first loan in the amount of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts. She intends to use the additional revenue generated from the business to financially support the immediate members of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 34 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk, and small business entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to make additional handicrafts to offer for sale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy a new sewing machine

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita T. is from the village of Brgy. Mangayang, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 54 years old. Clarita is married and has 6 adult children. To make a living, Clarita owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising pigs for breeding. Clarita has been engaged in her business for over 15 years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Clarita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Clarita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Clarita is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase livestock feed and other supplies. This loan will be the 2nd loan taken out by Clarita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase livestock feed & other supplies.

location.town: Brgy. Mangayang, Dupax del Sur, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Hamadi

texts.en:
Hamadi is a married man with three children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. 

Hamadi has operated his video show library for the past six years. The members of the neighboring community are his potential customers. Hamadi faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. When schools are open he gets fewer customers visiting his video library while during holiday season many customers visit the video library. 

With the Kshs 20,000 loan Hamadi  wants to purchase a big screen and a video player. In the future he hopes to open a bigger hall where he can show  films.

loans.use: To purchase a big screen and a video player.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en:
Esther is a married woman with two daughters, all of whom graduated from school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

For over ten years, she has operated a Leso’s (Kiko’s) selling business. She sells wholesale and retail from home to her neighbors, especially women. Esther faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.  She hopes to establish a cloth selling shop in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000,  she wants to purchase 10 pairs of Leso’s (Kiko’s) for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to improve her business.

loans.use: To purchase clothes for resale

loans.name: Hem

texts.en: Hem O., 47, is a farmer, earning an income of USD 2.5 per day. O. is married and resides with her husband and four children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. Her husband is employed to take care of the plantation, earning an income of USD 2 per day. The family has to spend USD 35 on food, USD 3 on electricity supply, and USD 60 on other necessary expenses every month. O. is requesting a loan of USD 600 to purchase more rice to resell. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house. This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia. O. was not available so her husband appears in the photograph instead.

loans.use: To buy rice to resell.

loans.name: Salamatu

texts.en:
This is 27-year-old Salamatu T.. She is married and has two children ages 4 and 6. 

In 2000, Salamatu T. established her local goods business, selling palm oil, pepper, rice and bananas. She began her business because she wanted to be self-employed and sustain herself. Working seven days a week and seven hours a day, she earns about  250,000 SLL every month. 

She would like a loan in the amount of 4,000,000 SLL in order to increase business. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately 300,000 SLL. 

In the future, Salamatu plans to educate her children, help her husband to support their family, and buy additional goods in larger quantities to sell in a nearby town or city. She thanks you for your support

loans.use: To buy additional palm oil

loans.name: Rimbert

texts.es:
El socio pertenece al banco comunal “CENTRAL PATAQUEHUAR”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Quiquijana, perteneciente a la provincia de Quispicanchis y departamento de Cusco.

El socio es el Sr. Rimbert; el tiene 32 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos; El socio alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de ganados, el los hace engordar y luego lo vende en forma ambulatoria, el socio quiere ampliar el negocio de venta de ganados .El  socio solicita el préstamo para comprar ganados.

El socio está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Here is a member of communal bank named "Central Pataquehuar". It is located in the district of Quiquijana, belonging to the province of Quispicanchis and in the department of Cusco.

His name is Rimbert. He is 32 years old, married common-law, and the father of 2 children. He alternates his daily activities with his livestock business. He raises his livestock and later sells them itinerantly. He wishes to expand his livestock business. He requests a loan to purchase heads of cattle. 

He is happy to receive a loan and he is committed to making the payments of that loan.

loans.use: To purchase livestock.

loans.name: Magdaline

texts.en:
Magdaline is a married woman with one child who is still too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

She has been operating a goat fattening business for the past two years, selling the fattened goats at the market to her neighbours.  In her business, Magdaline faces a major challenge in the high cost of transporting her goats to the market. She hopes to expand and start a cow selling business in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan, she wants to purchase goats to fatten and sell. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase goats for sale

loans.name: Sheila

texts.en:
Sheila is a 38-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating hog raising and livestock businesses. She lives in Danao City, Cebu.  She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2009 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her hog raising and livestocks businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 9,000. Sheila is borrowing PHP 11,000 to purchase livestock supplies.  This will be her fourth loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Sheila aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To purchase livestock supplies

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles is a 25-year-old married man with three children who owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. He has been in a retail shop for eight years which he started with capital of 70,000 shillings and now has 7,000,000 shillings. He experiences hardship due to price fluctuation and his vision is a wholesale business plus educating his children. Charles needs the loan to buy soap, sugar and rice to sell.

loans.use: To buy soap, sugar and rice to sell

loans.name: Ovidio

texts.es: Ovidio, de 40 años, es un padre de familia muy alegre y trabajador, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposa Reyda de 35 años y sus 5 queridos hijos, quienes son el motivo de todos sus esfuerzos. La actividad a la que Ovidio se dedica, es el cultivo de papas, choclos, olluco y arvejas, Todos los días, muy temprano por la mañana, trabaja en su cultivo, ya que sabe que mientras mejor calidad tengan sus productos, mejores precios obtendrá por sus productos en el mercado mayorista de Tarma. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cosechar sus tierras, ya que así siente que los meses de trabajo han tenido sus frutos, lleva 33 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es fumigar sus tierras, puesto que siempre corre el peligro de que los químicos le causen alguna enfermedad. Con el tiempo, desea comprar más tierras, para sembrar más. Este es el segunda crédito con MFP, manifiesta que el crédito le ayudará mucho en el progreso de su trabajo. En su banco comunal, es un socio muy responsable y respetuoso. Con los mil quinientos nuevos soles solicitados, comprará semillas de papa y arveja, ya que en esta temporada son los productos que mejor se venderán.
texts.en:
Ovidio is 40 years old.  He is a very cheerful and hard-working father who lives in his own home together with his wife, 35 year-old Reyda, and his 5 beloved children who are the motivation behind all his efforts.  Ovidio's business is growing potatoes, corn, olluco (a native tuber) and peas.  Every day, very early in the morning, he works on his crops since he knows that the better the quality of his crops, the better the prices he will obtain for them in the wholesale market in Tarma.

What Ovidio most enjoys about his work is harvesting his land since that is when he feels that the months of work have borne fruit.  He has been in this business for 33 years and considers the most difficult part of his work to be spraying his land since he always runs the risk of the chemicals making him sick.  Over time, he would like to buy more land so that he can grow more crops.

This is Ovidio's second loan from MFP and he says that the loan will help him a lot in making progress in his work.  He is a very responsible and respectful member of his community bank.  He will use the 1,500 Peruvian soles he has requested to buy potato and pea seeds since, during this season, they are the products that well best.

loans.use: to buy potato and pea seeds

loans.name: Ihab

texts.ar: ايهاب عمره 39 سنة متزوج وله 3 اولاد يعمل في مطعم لبيع الفروج والسمك وغيره من الاطعمة له في عمله 11 سنة يحب العمل ويتميز عمله بالدقة والنظافة يريد ان يطور عمله حتى يتمكن من تحسين وضع عائلته المادي والاجتماعي فهو يحب لعائلته التحسن في الوضع المادي والاجتماعي يريد من خلال طلب قرض من المجموعة الى شراء عدة جديدة للمحل ثلاجة للسمك و منشار كهرباء ومكنة تغليف له زبائن من محيطه وجيرانه واقاربه يحلم بتطوير عمله وتحسين المبيع لديه حتى يتمكن من تطوير العمل من محل صغير الى مطعم كبير يتمكن من استقبال عدد اكبر من الزبائن فهو يتميز بطموحه الغير محدود ولرغبته بتحسين وضعه المادي
texts.en: Ihab, 39, is married with three children. He has been working for 11 years at a small restaurant that sells chicken, fish, and other foods. He is known at work for his perfection and hygiene. Ihab wants to promote his business. He loves his family and wishes to raise its financiA. and sociA. status. Ihab wants a loan from A. Majmoua to buy new equipment for his restaurant: fridge for fish, power saw, and packing machine.His clients are mainly from his neighbours, relatives and those who know him. He wishes to expand his business and to turn his small restaurant into a big one so that he can receive more clients. Ihab is very ambitious and wishes to raise his standard of living.

loans.use: To buy a fridge, power saw, and packing machine for his restaurant.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Jacob Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Dora is a humble and kind 36-year-old lady. She is married, but does not have any children. Her husband is a service provider.  She loves trading, especially as a source of livelihood. She sells fish and meat to households and food vendors in her town, Berekum, in northern Ghana. Fish and meat are commonly used animal proteins in the preparation of soups and sauces in many households and food establishments in Ghana. Their trade is, indeed, a lucrative source of income for many women like Dora.  She has sold fish and meat for the past three years. She plans to use the loan to purchase assorted fish and meat in cartons to fill her demand. Dora dreams of one day being able to expand her business and make more profits, even to the point of supporting the poor in her community, and providing her mum with decent accommodation. 

Dora is currently the leader of a five-member trust bank group called Jacob Trust Bank. The other members are neighbors who also trade in various items. Members of the group use peer guarantees to secure their loans, and to provide assistance to one another in times of difficulty to settle their repayments.

loans.use: to purchase assorted fish and meat.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase silk threads in a variety of colors.

loans.name: Victor Alfredo

texts.es:
En la ciudadela nueva california de la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Nueva Jerusalén.
 
Aquí conocimos a Víctor, tiene 38 años de edad, es soltero y vive en una casa que alquila junto a una hermana.

Se dedica al comercio, vende periódicos, revistas, tarjetas y recargas telefónicas, tiene un puesto en el mercado # 1 de la ciudad de Portoviejo, trabaja todos los días desde 04h30 hasta las 13h30. En las tardes también se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, esto lo hace puerta a puerta. Nos cuenta que lleva 30 años en lo que es venta de periódicos pues empezó desde niño y en lo que es ropa lleva 10 años, ahora espera invertir este crédito y aumentar su negocio. La ropa compra en Guayaquil cada vez que necesita.

Este crédito lo va a invertir en comprar boletos de lotería para la venta, revistas, ropa de todo tipo, recargas y tarjetas telefónicas. Este es su cuarto ciclo en el Banco Comunal y le gusta por los beneficios que le dan los créditos para su negocio.
 
Sus sueños son tener un negocio más grande y mejorar dia a dia.
texts.en:
Every fortnight the members of the 'La California' community bank meet in the Nueva California district of the city of Portoviejo, the capital of Manabí, which has been known for many years as the city of the royal tamarind trees.

This is where we meet Victor, age 38.  He is single, and he lives in a rented house with his sister.  He sells newspapers, magazines, cards, phone cards, and phone minutes.  He has a stand at the #1 market in the city of Portoviejo.  He works every day from 4:30 until 1:30.  He also sells all types of clothes in the afternoons.  He does this door to door.  He tells us that he has been selling newspapers for 30 years.  He started as a boy.  He has been selling clothes for ten years. 

He plans to use this loan to increase his business.  When he needs clothes, he buys them in Guayaquil. 
He will use this loan to buy lottery tickets to sell, magazines, all types of clothes, and telephone cards and minutes.  

This is his fourth cycle in his communal bank.  He likes it because of the benefits the loans bring to his business.

His dream is to, day to day, have a bigger and better business.

loans.use: to buy lottery tickets to sell, magazines, all types of clothes, and telephone cards and minutes.

loans.name: Leah

texts.en:
Leah has practiced farming in Ndunyu Njeru town for the last 11 years. She is 32 years old, married to Karanu, and they have three school-going children.  

She was introduced to KADET by one of our field officers and this will be her second loan. She paid her previous loan of KES 40,000 well and in good time. 

She plans to use the loan amount to buy a milking cow as she looks to start mixed farming.

In the future, Leah hopes to become a leading mixed farmer in the Ndunyu Njeru area.

loans.use: To buy a dairy cow.

loans.name: Patricia

texts.es: Patricia nació en la ciudad de Lima (Perú) y tiene 54 años de edad. Actualmente, Patricia vive en la ciudad del Cusco junto con su único hijo.  Patricia se dedica a la venta de artesanía (Tejidos Planos) en el mercado de Chinchero desde las 8 de la mañana hasta las 7 de la noche. Ya son varios años que se dedica a este negocio y le va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone en su trabajo. En esta oportunidad requiere el préstamo para comprar más materiales como por ejemplo lana, hilos y otras cosas más. La socia es una persona responsable y trabajadora que por esas cualidades sus compañeras le invitaron a participar del banco comunal la “Inti Quilla” de la Asociación Arariwa.
texts.en: Patricia was born in the city of Lima (Perú) and she is 54 years old. At present, Patricia lives in the city of Cuzco with her only son. Patricia sells artisanal crafts (tejidos planos) in the market of Chinchero from 8 in the morning until 7 at night. She has been in this business for several years, and it is going very well for her thanks to the dedication she brings to her work. At this time, she needs the loan to buy more materials, such as wool, thread and other things. She is a responsible and hardworking person and because of these qualities the other members invited her to join the community bank called “Inti Quilla” of the Asociación Arariwa.

loans.use: to buy more materials.

loans.name: Emelda

texts.en:
Emelda is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a sari-sari store business in the Philippines. She is borrowing 20,000 PHP through Kiva partner, NWTF, to purchase more stocks of soft drinks to sell in her store.
Emelda has been in this business for a year. She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She dreams of building and expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of soft drinks to sell.

loans.name: Sabina Del Carmen

texts.es: Sabina es una mujer de 56 años, vive en el reparto modesto palma. Sabina se dedica a una pulpería  ubicada en su vivienda la mayoría de sus clientes llegan a comprar los productos que ofrece. Ella tiene este negocio desde hace 30 años y las ganancias obtenidas le permiten darle comodidades a su familia. Es por ello que Sabina desea invertir en su actividad. Solicita el crédito para comprar golosinas, refrescos, granos básicos, cremas, leches, pan, detergentes entre otras cosas. Ella solo ha trabajado con nuestra institución y cuenta con un excelente récord de pagos. Estaría muy agradecida de concedérsele el crédito.
texts.en:
Sabina is 56 and lives in the Modesto Palma neighborhood of Leon in Nicaragua.  She has a grocery store located in her home, where her clients come to buy her products.  She has had this business for 30 years, and the income from it has allowed her to make her family more comfortable.  It is for this reason that Sabina wants to invest in this business.  

She is seeking a loan to buy sweets, soft drinks, staples, cream, milk, bread, and detergents, among other things.  She has worked only with microfinance partner Fundación Leon and has an excellent payment record.  She is very grateful to receive this loan.

loans.use: to buy sweets, soft drinks, staples, cream, milk, bread, and detergent, among other things.

loans.name: Juvin Prisla

texts.fr:
Client  âgé 30 ans et marié sans enfant. Par manque d’appui considérable pour ses études, il s’est lancé dans la vente des produits de santé. Au regard de la fréquence des clients et la rareté des produits, le crédit octroyé lui permettra de renforcer son stock.
Pour assurer la croissance de son activité et la réalisation de l’ambition  de devenir Grossiste, il envisage beaucoup épargner. Très entrepreneur, il fait face aux obligations de son statut et fait l’objet de bon témoignage dans sa communauté.
texts.en:
The client is 30 years old and married without children. Due to lack of sufficient support for his studies, he began a business selling health products. Given the frequency of clients and the scarcity of products, the credit granted will enable him to reinforce his stock.
To ensure the growth of his business and to achieve his goal of becoming a wholesaler, he hopes to save alot. Very entrepreneurial, he lives up to his obligations and is well regarded in the community.

loans.use: renforcer le stock des produits pharmaceutiques

loans.name: Jasmin

texts.en:
Jasmin is a mother of 3 school-age dependents living in Aurora, Zamboanga del Sur, Philippines. She owns a motorcycle for transport. This is a habal-habal, as the folks have called it. It is capable of carrying 2-4 passengers. This business was started 5 years ago and continues serving community members today. A total of about PHP 5,000 a month is generated.

Motorcycle parts may be broken or damaged at any time. To maintain the vehicle in good running condition, Jasmin applied for a loan of PHP 5,000 at GDMPC earlier this year. This will be used to purchase motor tires and accessories to continue pursuing business operations. By having all this fixed, Jasmin hopes to gain more income and to expand the vehicle seating capacity in the future.

loans.use: To purchase motor tires and accessories.

loans.name: Ivan Cruz

texts.es:
Ivan tiene 25 años de edad, es soltero, vive en su casa de sus padres, cuenta con servicio sólo de agua, ubicada en la zona rural del departamento de Lambayeque.  Esta zona tiene como actividad agricultura, ganadería y turismo. 

Ivan desde hace varios años se dedica a la crianza y venta de ganado vacuno (vaca), su corral se encuentra en la parte externa de su casa, los alimenta con comida balanceada y pastos naturales, una vez que sus animales llegan a su crecimiento óptimo podrá ofrecerlos en los diferentes mercados de la zona y así pueda obtener muy buenas ganancias para solventar sus gastos familiares.  

Ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 2000 nuevos soles para comprar más animales de otras especies, alimento y adaptación de un nuevo corral, con la finalidad de obtener más clientes e ingresos y así mejoraría  su calidad de vida.  Ivan es una persona trabajadora y responsable que lo único que desea es que su negocio crezca para seguir ayudando a sus padres y mejorando él mismo.
texts.en:
Ivan is 25 years old, single, and lives in his parent’s home, which has running water, located in the rural area of the department of Lambayeque. This zone is known for agriculture, livestock and tourism.

For some years Ivan has been raising and selling cattle (cows). He has a corral outside his house. He gives them animal feed and natural pasture. When the animals reach their optimum size he offers them for sale in various markets in the area, and thus can attain a good income to meet his family expenses.

He is asking for a loan from Edpyme Alternativa of 2000 soles in order to buy other breeds of animals, and feed, and to redo his corral with the goal of obtaining more clients and income, thereby improving the quality of his life. Ivan is a responsible and hard working person who only wants his business to grow in order to continue helping his parents and to improve himself.

loans.use: to buy other breeds of animals and to redo the corral

loans.name: Naseem's Group

texts.en:
Naseem has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the betterment of her livestock business. With the loan, she will buy goats and sheep. She will raise them up by giving them good food and then sell on EID (Muslims occasion) and to butchers for profits. 

Naseem is the mother of 7 children. Her daughters are staff nurses while her sons are getting their education. Her husband is 71 years old and can’t do work at such an older age so he stays at home. 
Naseem also carries out her responsibilities of a housewife as well.  

Naseem is hopeful that through the loan investment she will be able to improve the financial condition of her business and her family.

loans.use: To buy goats & sheep for her livestock business

loans.name: Absa

texts.fr: Habitant dans une ville située à l'ouest du Sénégal,son activité principale est le commerce.Ce prêt est destinée à l'achat de produits halieutiques (poissons fumées, poissons séchées) et d'autres produits de mer pour les revendre sur le marché local. Vue que son activité marche bien, elle veut augmenter son pouvoir d'achat pour mieux répondre à la demande des clients. Elle veut aussi appuyer son mari sur les dépenses quotidiennes de la maison avec le bénéfice qu'elle a dans son commerce
texts.en: This borrower lives in a town in the west of Senegal.  Her main business activity is buying and selling.  She will use this loan to buy fish (smoked fish and dried fish) and other seafood to sell in her local market.  As her business is doing well, she would like to increase her purchasing power in order to better respond to her customer demand.  She would also like to support her husband in covering their daily household expenses through the profits that she makes in her business.

loans.use: to buy fish and seafood

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a single woman with two school-going children. She lives in a rental house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food for her family and school fees for her children. 

She has operated a food stall for the past three years; her potential clients are the local area residents. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. She dreams of opening another type of business like a cereals shop. 

With the 15,000 Kenyan Shilling (KES) loan she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil for her food stall. She decided to join Yehu because of easy access to loan facilities.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and cooking oil for her food stall.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth is a 32 year-old married woman. She has a child who is 3 years old. She describes herself to be loving. She operates a clothing business where she sells clothes to the local people. She has been involved in this business for 4 years and employs 1 staff member. Her business is located in a shopping centre. She describes her biggest business challenge to be insufficient capital. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to add to her stock of clothes.
